comment_text.mn82:1.1: The story of Raṭṭhapāla, the “guardian of the nation”, has become one of the most famous and beloved parables from early Buddhism. It is a testament to a young man’s resolution to go forth out of faith, a quality for which he was later honored (AN 1.210:1.1). But the power of Raṭṭhapāla’s determination should not overshadow the moving conversation he has with King Koravya at the end.
comment_text.mn82:1.2: Thullakoṭṭhika (“place of fat granaries”; Sanskrit sthūlakoṣṭhaka) only appears in the story of Raṭṭhapāla.
comment_text.mn82:4.3: From this point, the narrative is largely echoed in the story of Sudinna (Bu Pj 1:5.1.7), with, however, a very different outcome. While the exact relationship between these shared narratives is not easy to determine, it seems likely that Sudinna’s story adopted elements of Raṭṭhapāla’s.
comment_text.mn82:6.6: This Vinaya rule is not mentioned elsewhere in the suttas, although it was required also of Sudinna (Bu Pj 1:5.1.14). It was instituted on the emotional request of the Buddha’s own father, who was distraught when his grandson Rāhula went forth while still a boy (Kd 1:54.4.2). It originally applied to novices, who went forth as young as fifteen or “when old enough to scare crows” (Kd 1:51.1.14). Over time the requirements for ordination tend to become stricter as things required in a particular context are applied generally. If this is the case here, the process must have happened quickly, so that even in the canonical full ordination procedure a candidate, who must be twenty years at least, must have permission of their parents (Kd 1:76.1.12). However, there are many people who cannot get such permission, such as orphans. Thus if one does give the going-forth to someone without permission of the parents, it is a minor offence of wrong-doing for the mendicant performing the ordination, but it does not invalidate it (Kd 1:54.6.5).
comment_text.mn82:7.21: A similar method was employed by Bhaddā Kuṇḍalakesā, according to the commentary to Thig 5.9. She lay face down until her parents allowed her to marry the man she desired, who was, unfortunately, a convicted criminal. The marriage did not end well, but she persevered and ultimately triumphed.
comment_text.mn82:14.1: While the conventional phrase “soon” (nacirasseva) is used, the commentary says it was twelve years, which would explain why his family did not immediately recognize him.
comment_text.mn82:17.1: This is a sign of the dandified life expected of Raṭṭhapāla. Hairstyles for upper class men of the time were quite fancy, or at least they are depicted so in the early sculptures at Sanchi.
comment_text.mn82:18.4: This detail is remarkably similar to the Odyssey 19:361–475, where due to the marks on his feet, the maidservant Eurycleia recognizes Odysseus on his return even though his own wife did not.
comment_text.mn82:19.3: The same syntax recurs at AN 5.166:11.2, where it is clear the future tense expresses indignation rather than future time.
comment_text.mn82:19.4: In the Vinaya, the exchange between Raṭṭhapāla and his father is expressed in verse (Bu Ss 6:1.5.1).
comment_text.mn82:23.3: Raṭṭhapāla refers to his former wives as sisters, an indication that he sees them in accordance with the advice in SN 35.127:1.6, to regard women of one’s one age as a sister. Notably, he has already used the same respectful term when addressing the household maid, whereas his mother uses the disrespectful “wench” (je).
comment_text.mn82:25.1: The following verses are also found in Raṭṭhapāla’s verses at Thag 16.4.
comment_text.mn82:27.1: Koravya (Sanskrit kauravya or kaurava) is the conventional name for descendants of the legendary Kuru, founding king of the Kurus.
comment_text.mn82:30.9: While Raṭṭhapāla’s age is not given, he seems quite young when he went forth. He addresses his parents with the familiar “mum and dad”; permission of his parents is required; his friends play a major role influencing his decisions; and he lies on the ground refusing to move until he gets what he wants from his parents. All this sounds like a teenager. True, he was married, but such marriages could be arranged young. And now here, twelve years later according to the commentary, he is still a young man.
comment_text.mn82:35.1: While these four summaries reflect key teachings of the Buddha, they are not found as such in early texts.
comment_text.mn82:38.5: For alamatto read alamattho, “capable”.
comment_text.mn82:41.23: This is a rare acknowledgement of the existence of lands over the seas.
comment_text.mn82:41.35: This passage is a counterweight to the ideal of the Wheel-turning Monarch, who “after conquering this land girt by sea, reigns by principle, without rod or sword” (eg. MN 91:5.8). The Wheel-turning Monarch is in turn a Buddhist recasting of the Brahmanical notion of a king who rules by favor of the gods as demonstrated in the horse sacrifice. The idea of a righteous king whom all obey without coercion belongs rightly to legend, while as Raṭṭhapāla so eloquently, not to mention bravely, points out, the very desire to rule is founded on craving.
comment_text.mn82:42.48: Virūparūpena appears at DN 24:1.17.8, Ja 522:18.3, and Ja 526:56.2, where it always has the meaning “in disguise”.
comment_text.mn82:42.51: Māṇava, which normally means “Vedic student”, is occasionally used in the poetic sense of manussa (“humans”). Both words mean “descendant of the first man, Manu”.

root_text.mn82:13.3: Anupubbena cārikaṁ caramāno yena sāvatthi tadavasari.
root_text.mn82:13.4: Tatra sudaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn82:14.1: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṁ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
root_text.mn82:14.2: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
root_text.mn82:14.3: Aññataro kho panāyasmā raṭṭhapālo arahataṁ ahosi.
root_text.mn82:15.1: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn82:15.2: “icchāmahaṁ, bhante, mātāpitaro uddassetuṁ, sace maṁ bhagavā anujānātī”ti.
root_text.mn82:15.3: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa cetasā ceto paricca manasākāsi.
root_text.mn82:15.5: “abhabbo kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattitun”ti, atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṁ raṭṭhapālaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn82:16.1: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā senāsanaṁ saṁsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena thullakoṭṭhikaṁ tena cārikaṁ pakkāmi.
root_text.mn82:16.2: Anupubbena cārikaṁ caramāno yena thullakoṭṭhiko tadavasari.
root_text.mn82:16.3: Tatra sudaṁ āyasmā raṭṭhapālo thullakoṭṭhike viharati rañño korabyassa migacīre.
root_text.mn82:16.4: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya thullakoṭṭhikaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
root_text.mn82:16.5: Thullakoṭṭhike sapadānaṁ piṇḍāya caramāno yena sakapitu nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.mn82:17.1: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā majjhimāya dvārasālāya ullikhāpeti.
root_text.mn82:17.2: Addasā kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā āyasmantaṁ raṭṭhapālaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
root_text.mn82:17.4: “imehi muṇḍakehi samaṇakehi amhākaṁ ekaputtako piyo manāpo pabbājito”ti.
root_text.mn82:17.5: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo sakapitu nivesane neva dānaṁ alattha na paccakkhānaṁ;
root_text.mn82:18.1: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa ñātidāsī ābhidosikaṁ kummāsaṁ chaḍḍetukāmā hoti.
root_text.mn82:18.2: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo taṁ ñātidāsiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn82:18.3: “sacetaṁ, bhagini, chaḍḍanīyadhammaṁ, idha me patte ākirā”ti.
root_text.mn82:18.4: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa ñātidāsī taṁ ābhidosikaṁ kummāsaṁ āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa patte ākirantī hatthānañca pādānañca sarassa ca nimittaṁ aggahesi.
root_text.mn82:18.5: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa ñātidāsī yenāyasmato raṭṭhapālassa mātā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa mātaraṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn82:18.8: “Sace, je, saccaṁ bhaṇasi, adāsiṁ taṁ karomī”ti.
root_text.mn82:18.9: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa mātā yenāyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitaraṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn82:19.1: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā raṭṭhapālo taṁ ābhidosikaṁ kummāsaṁ aññataraṁ kuṭṭamūlaṁ nissāya paribhuñjati.
root_text.mn82:19.2: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā yenāyasmā raṭṭhapālo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ raṭṭhapālaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn82:19.3: “atthi nāma, tāta raṭṭhapāla, ābhidosikaṁ kummāsaṁ paribhuñjissasi?
root_text.mn82:19.4: Nanu, tāta raṭṭhapāla, sakaṁ gehaṁ gantabban”ti?
root_text.mn82:19.5: “Kuto no, gahapati, amhākaṁ gehaṁ agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitānaṁ?
root_text.mn82:19.7: Agamamha kho te, gahapati, gehaṁ, tattha neva dānaṁ alatthamha na paccakkhānaṁ;
root_text.mn82:19.11: “Tena hi, tāta raṭṭhapāla, adhivāsehi svātanāya bhattan”ti.
root_text.mn82:20.1: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa adhivāsanaṁ viditvā yena sakaṁ nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mahantaṁ hiraññasuvaṇṇassa puñjaṁ kārāpetvā kilañjehi paṭicchādetvā āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa purāṇadutiyikā āmantesi:
root_text.mn82:20.2: “etha tumhe, vadhuyo, yena alaṅkārena alaṅkatā pubbe raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa piyā hotha manāpā tena alaṅkārena alaṅkarothā”ti.
root_text.mn82:21.1: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā tassā rattiyā accayena sake nivesane paṇītaṁ khādanīyaṁ bhojanīyaṁ paṭiyādāpetvā āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa kālaṁ ārocesi:
root_text.mn82:22.1: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena sakapitu nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā taṁ hiraññasuvaṇṇassa puñjaṁ vivarāpetvā āyasmantaṁ raṭṭhapālaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn82:22.2: “idaṁ te, tāta raṭṭhapāla, mātu mattikaṁ dhanaṁ, aññaṁ pettikaṁ, aññaṁ pitāmahaṁ.
root_text.mn82:22.3: Sakkā, tāta raṭṭhapāla, bhoge ca bhuñjituṁ puññāni ca kātuṁ.
root_text.mn82:22.4: Ehi tvaṁ, tāta raṭṭhapāla, hīnāyāvattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjassu puññāni ca karohī”ti.
root_text.mn82:22.5: “Sace me tvaṁ, gahapati, vacanaṁ kareyyāsi, imaṁ hiraññasuvaṇṇassa puñjaṁ sakaṭe āropetvā nibbāhāpetvā majjhegaṅgāya nadiyā sote opilāpeyyāsi.
root_text.mn82:22.7: Ye uppajjissanti hi te, gahapati, tatonidānaṁ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.
root_text.mn82:23.1: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa purāṇadutiyikā paccekaṁ pādesu gahetvā āyasmantaṁ raṭṭhapālaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn82:23.2: “kīdisā nāma tā, ayyaputta, accharāyo yāsaṁ tvaṁ hetu brahmacariyaṁ carasī”ti?
root_text.mn82:23.3: “Na kho mayaṁ, bhaginī, accharānaṁ hetu brahmacariyaṁ carāmā”ti.
root_text.mn82:23.4: “Bhaginivādena no ayyaputto raṭṭhapālo samudācaratī”ti tā tattheva mucchitā papatiṁsu.
root_text.mn82:24.1: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo pitaraṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn82:24.5: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā āyasmantaṁ raṭṭhapālaṁ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
root_text.mn82:24.6: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo bhuttāvī onītapattapāṇī ṭhitakova imā gāthā abhāsi:
root_text.mn82:26.1: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo ṭhitakova imā gāthā bhāsitvā yena rañño korabyassa migacīraṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn82:27.1: Atha kho rājā korabyo migavaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn82:27.4: “Evaṁ, devā”ti kho migavo rañño korabyassa paṭissutvā migacīraṁ sodhento addasa āyasmantaṁ raṭṭhapālaṁ aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṁ nisinnaṁ.
root_text.mn82:27.5: Disvāna yena rājā korabyo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṁ korabyaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn82:27.7: Atthi cettha raṭṭhapālo nāma kulaputto imasmiṁyeva thullakoṭṭhike aggakulassa putto yassa tvaṁ abhiṇhaṁ kittayamāno ahosi, so aññatarasmiṁ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṁ nisinno”ti.
root_text.mn82:27.8: “Tena hi, samma migava, alaṁ dānajja uyyānabhūmiyā.
root_text.mn82:27.9: Tameva dāni mayaṁ bhavantaṁ raṭṭhapālaṁ payirupāsissāmā”ti.
root_text.mn82:28.1: Atha kho rājā korabyo “yaṁ tattha khādanīyaṁ bhojanīyaṁ paṭiyattaṁ taṁ sabbaṁ vissajjethā”ti vatvā bhadrāni bhadrāni yānāni yojāpetvā bhadraṁ yānaṁ abhiruhitvā bhadrehi bhadrehi yānehi thullakoṭṭhikamhā niyyāsi mahaccarājānubhāvena āyasmantaṁ raṭṭhapālaṁ dassanāya.
root_text.mn82:28.2: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova ussaṭāya ussaṭāya parisāya yenāyasmā raṭṭhapālo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā raṭṭhapālena saddhiṁ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho rājā korabyo āyasmantaṁ raṭṭhapālaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn82:28.6: Nisīdi rājā korabyo paññatte āsane. Nisajja kho rājā korabyo āyasmantaṁ raṭṭhapālaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn82:29.1: “Cattārimāni, bho raṭṭhapāla, pārijuññāni yehi pārijuññehi samannāgatā idhekacce kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti.
root_text.mn82:30.2: Idha, bho raṭṭhapāla, ekacco jiṇṇo hoti vuḍḍho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto.
root_text.mn82:30.4: ‘ahaṁ khomhi etarahi jiṇṇo vuḍḍho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto.
root_text.mn82:30.5: Na kho pana mayā sukaraṁ anadhigataṁ vā bhogaṁ adhigantuṁ adhigataṁ vā bhogaṁ phātiṁ kātuṁ.
root_text.mn82:30.6: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
root_text.mn82:30.7: So tena jarāpārijuññena samannāgato kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.mn82:30.9: Bhavaṁ kho pana raṭṭhapālo etarahi daharo yuvā susukāḷakeso bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato paṭhamena vayasā.
root_text.mn82:30.11: Kiṁ bhavaṁ raṭṭhapālo ñatvā vā disvā vā sutvā vā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito?
root_text.mn82:31.2: Idha, bho raṭṭhapāla, ekacco ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
root_text.mn82:31.5: Na kho pana mayā sukaraṁ anadhigataṁ vā bhogaṁ adhigantuṁ adhigataṁ vā bhogaṁ phātiṁ kātuṁ.
root_text.mn82:31.6: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
root_text.mn82:31.7: So tena byādhipārijuññena samannāgato kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.mn82:31.9: Bhavaṁ kho pana raṭṭhapālo etarahi appābādho appātaṅko samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya.
root_text.mn82:31.11: Kiṁ bhavaṁ raṭṭhapālo ñatvā vā disvā vā sutvā vā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito?
root_text.mn82:32.2: Idha, bho raṭṭhapāla, ekacco aḍḍho hoti mahaddhano mahābhogo.
root_text.mn82:32.3: Tassa te bhogā anupubbena parikkhayaṁ gacchanti.
root_text.mn82:32.5: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe aḍḍho ahosiṁ mahaddhano mahābhogo.
root_text.mn82:32.6: Tassa me te bhogā anupubbena parikkhayaṁ gatā.
root_text.mn82:32.7: Na kho pana mayā sukaraṁ anadhigataṁ vā bhogaṁ adhigantuṁ adhigataṁ vā bhogaṁ phātiṁ kātuṁ.
root_text.mn82:32.8: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
root_text.mn82:32.9: So tena bhogapārijuññena samannāgato kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.mn82:32.11: Bhavaṁ kho pana raṭṭhapālo imasmiṁyeva thullakoṭṭhike aggakulassa putto.
root_text.mn82:32.13: Kiṁ bhavaṁ raṭṭhapālo ñatvā vā disvā vā sutvā vā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito?
root_text.mn82:33.2: Idha, bho raṭṭhapāla, ekaccassa bahū honti mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā.
root_text.mn82:33.3: Tassa te ñātakā anupubbena parikkhayaṁ gacchanti.
root_text.mn82:33.5: ‘mamaṁ kho pubbe bahū ahesuṁ mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā.
root_text.mn82:33.6: Tassa me te anupubbena parikkhayaṁ gatā.
root_text.mn82:33.7: Na kho pana mayā sukaraṁ anadhigataṁ vā bhogaṁ adhigantuṁ adhigataṁ vā bhogaṁ phātiṁ kātuṁ.
root_text.mn82:33.8: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
root_text.mn82:33.9: So tena ñātipārijuññena samannāgato kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
root_text.mn82:33.11: Bhoto kho pana raṭṭhapālassa imasmiṁyeva thullakoṭṭhike bahū mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā.
root_text.mn82:33.13: Kiṁ bhavaṁ raṭṭhapālo ñatvā vā disvā vā sutvā vā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito?
root_text.mn82:34.1: Imāni kho, bho raṭṭhapāla, cattāri pārijuññāni, yehi pārijuññehi samannāgatā idhekacce kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajanti.
root_text.mn82:34.3: Kiṁ bhavaṁ raṭṭhapālo ñatvā vā disvā vā sutvā vā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito”ti?
root_text.mn82:35.1: “Atthi kho, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro dhammuddesā uddiṭṭhā, ye ahaṁ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.
root_text.mn82:36.2: kho, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena paṭhamo dhammuddeso uddiṭṭho, yamahaṁ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.
root_text.mn82:36.4: kho, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dutiyo dhammuddeso uddiṭṭho, yamahaṁ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.
root_text.mn82:36.6: kho, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena tatiyo dhammuddeso uddiṭṭho, yamahaṁ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.
root_text.mn82:36.8: kho, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena catuttho dhammuddeso uddiṭṭho, yamahaṁ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.
root_text.mn82:37.1: Ime kho, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro dhammuddesā uddiṭṭhā, ye ahaṁ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito”ti.
root_text.mn82:38.3: Imassa, bho raṭṭhapāla, bhāsitassa kathaṁ attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
root_text.mn82:38.5: tvaṁ vīsativassuddesikopi paṇṇavīsativassuddesikopi hatthismimpi katāvī assasmimpi katāvī rathasmimpi katāvī dhanusmimpi katāvī tharusmimpi katāvī ūrubalī bāhubalī alamatto saṅgāmāvacaro”ti?
root_text.mn82:38.6: “Ahosiṁ ahaṁ, bho raṭṭhapāla, vīsativassuddesikopi paṇṇavīsativassuddesikopi hatthismimpi katāvī assasmimpi katāvī rathasmimpi katāvī dhanusmimpi katāvī tharusmimpi katāvī ūrubalī bāhubalī alamatto saṅgāmāvacaro.
root_text.mn82:38.7: Appekadāhaṁ, bho raṭṭhapāla, iddhimāva maññe na attano balena samasamaṁ samanupassāmī”ti.
root_text.mn82:38.9: evameva tvaṁ etarahi ūrubalī bāhubalī alamatto saṅgāmāvacaro”ti?
root_text.mn82:38.11: Etarahi jiṇṇo vuḍḍho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto āsītiko me vayo vattati.
root_text.mn82:38.12: Appekadāhaṁ, bho raṭṭhapāla, ‘idha pādaṁ karissāmī’ti aññeneva pādaṁ karomī”ti.
root_text.mn82:38.13: “Idaṁ kho taṁ, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sandhāya bhāsitaṁ:
root_text.mn82:38.15: yamahaṁ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito”ti.
root_text.mn82:38.17: Yāva subhāsitañcidaṁ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena:
root_text.mn82:38.19: Upaniyyati hi, bho raṭṭhapāla, loko addhuvo.
root_text.mn82:39.1: Saṁvijjante kho, bho raṭṭhapāla, imasmiṁ rājakule hatthikāyāpi assakāyāpi rathakāyāpi pattikāyāpi, amhākaṁ āpadāsu pariyodhāya vattissanti.
root_text.mn82:39.4: Imassa pana, bho raṭṭhapāla, bhāsitassa kathaṁ attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
root_text.mn82:39.8: Appekadā maṁ, bho raṭṭhapāla, mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā parivāretvā ṭhitā honti:
root_text.mn82:39.9: ‘idāni rājā korabyo kālaṁ karissati, idāni rājā korabyo kālaṁ karissatī’”ti.

translation_text.mn82:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kurus together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a town of the Kurus named Thullakoṭṭhika.
translation_text.mn82:2.1: The brahmins and householders of Thullakoṭṭhika heard:
translation_text.mn82:2.2: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Thullakoṭṭhika, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
translation_text.mn82:2.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.mn82:2.5: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.mn82:2.6: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
translation_text.mn82:2.7: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
translation_text.mn82:3.1: Then the brahmins and householders of Thullakoṭṭhika went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.
translation_text.mn82:3.2: When they were seated, the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.
translation_text.mn82:4.1: Now at that time a gentleman named Raṭṭhapāla, the son of the leading clan in Thullakoṭṭhika, was sitting in the assembly.
translation_text.mn82:4.3: “As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
translation_text.mn82:4.4: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”
translation_text.mn82:5.1: Then, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, the brahmins and householders of Thullakoṭṭhika got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.
translation_text.mn82:6.1: Soon after they left, Raṭṭhapāla went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.mn82:6.2: “Sir, as I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
translation_text.mn82:6.3: I wish to shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn82:6.4: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?
translation_text.mn82:6.5: May the Buddha please give me the going forth!”
translation_text.mn82:6.6: “But, Raṭṭhapāla, do you have your parents’ permission?”
translation_text.mn82:6.8: “Raṭṭhapāla, Buddhas don’t give the going forth to the child of parents who haven’t given their permission.”
translation_text.mn82:6.9: “I’ll make sure, sir, to get my parents’ permission.”
translation_text.mn82:7.1: Then Raṭṭhapāla got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha. Then he went to his parents and said,
translation_text.mn82:7.2: “Mum and dad, as I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
translation_text.mn82:7.3: I wish to shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn82:7.4: Please give me permission to go forth.”

translation_text.mn82:7.6: “But, dear Raṭṭhapāla, you’re our only child. You’re dear to us and we love you. You’re dainty and raised in comfort.
translation_text.mn82:7.8: Even when you die we will lose you against our wishes.
translation_text.mn82:7.9: So how can we allow you to go forth while you’re still alive?”
translation_text.mn82:7.11: and a third time, Raṭṭhapāla asked his parents for permission, but got the same reply.
translation_text.mn82:7.21: “My parents don’t allow me to go forth.” He laid down right there on the bare ground, saying,
translation_text.mn82:7.22: “I’ll either die right here or go forth.”
translation_text.mn82:7.23: And he refused to eat, up to the seventh meal.

translation_text.mn82:13.2: Not long after Venerable Raṭṭhapāla’s ordination, a fortnight later, the Buddha—having stayed in Thullakoṭṭhika as long as he pleased—set out for Sāvatthī.

translation_text.mn82:14.1: Then Venerable Raṭṭhapāla, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn82:14.2: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
translation_text.mn82:14.3: And Venerable Raṭṭhapāla became one of the perfected.

translation_text.mn82:16.1: And then Raṭṭhapāla got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Thullakoṭṭhika.
translation_text.mn82:16.2: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Thullakoṭṭhika,

translation_text.mn82:16.5: Wandering indiscriminately for almsfood, he approached his own father’s house.

translation_text.mn82:18.11: It seems our son Raṭṭhapāla has arrived.”

translation_text.mn82:19.2: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s father went up to him and said,
translation_text.mn82:19.3: “Dear Raṭṭhapāla! How can you be eating last night’s porridge?
translation_text.mn82:19.4: Why not go to your own home?”
translation_text.mn82:19.5: “Householder, how could those of us who have gone forth from the lay life to homelessness have a house?
translation_text.mn82:19.7: I came to your house, but there I received neither alms nor a polite refusal,
translation_text.mn82:19.9: “Come, dear Raṭṭhapāla, let’s go to the house.”
translation_text.mn82:19.10: “Enough, householder. My meal is finished for today.”
translation_text.mn82:19.11: “Well then, dear Raṭṭhapāla, please accept tomorrow’s meal from me.”
translation_text.mn82:20.1: Then, knowing that Raṭṭhapāla had consented, his father went back to his own house. He made a heap of gold, both coined and uncoined, and hid it under mats. Then he addressed Raṭṭhapāla’s former wives,
translation_text.mn82:20.2: “Please, daughters-in-law, adorn yourselves in the way that our son Raṭṭhapāla found you most adorable.”
translation_text.mn82:21.1: And when the night had passed Raṭṭhapāla’s father had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home, and announced the time to the Venerable Raṭṭhapāla, saying,
translation_text.mn82:21.2: “Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.”
translation_text.mn82:22.1: Then Raṭṭhapāla robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to his father’s home, and sat down on the seat spread out. Raṭṭhapāla’s father, revealing the heap of gold, both coined and uncoined, said to him,
translation_text.mn82:22.2: “Dear Raṭṭhapāla, this is your maternal fortune. There’s another paternal fortune, and an ancestral one.
translation_text.mn82:22.3: You can both enjoy your wealth and make merit.
translation_text.mn82:22.4: Come, return to a lesser life, enjoy wealth, and make merit!”
translation_text.mn82:22.5: “If you’d follow my advice, householder, you’d have this heap of gold, both coined and uncoined, loaded on a cart and carried away to be dumped in the middle of the Ganges river.
translation_text.mn82:22.7: Because this will bring you nothing but sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.”
translation_text.mn82:23.1: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s former wives each clasped his feet and said,
translation_text.mn82:23.2: “What are they like, master, the nymphs for whom you lead the spiritual life?”
translation_text.mn82:23.3: “Sisters, I don’t lead the spiritual life for the sake of nymphs.”
translation_text.mn82:23.4: Saying, “Our master Raṭṭhapāla addresses us as sisters!” they fainted right away.

translation_text.mn82:28.2: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached Raṭṭhapāla on foot, together with a group of eminent officials. translation_text.mn82:28.3: “Here, worthy Raṭṭhapāla, sit on this elephant rug.”
translation_text.mn82:28.4: “Enough, great king, you sit on it.
translation_text.mn82:28.5: I’m sitting on my own seat.”
translation_text.mn82:28.6: So the king sat down on the seat spread out, and said:
translation_text.mn82:29.1: “Worthy Raṭṭhapāla, there are these four kinds of decay. Because of these, some people shave off their hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.mn82:29.3: Decay due to old age, decay due to sickness, decay of wealth, and decay of relatives.
translation_text.mn82:30.1: And what is decay due to old age?
translation_text.mn82:30.2: It’s when someone is old, elderly, and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life.
translation_text.mn82:30.4: ‘I’m now old, elderly, and senior. I’m advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life.
translation_text.mn82:30.5: It’s not easy for me to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth I’ve already acquired.
translation_text.mn82:30.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
translation_text.mn82:30.7: So because of that decay due to old age they go forth.
translation_text.mn82:30.8: This is called decay due to old age.
translation_text.mn82:30.9: But worthy Raṭṭhapāla is now a youth, young, with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life.
translation_text.mn82:30.10: You have no decay due to old age.
translation_text.mn82:30.11: So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?
translation_text.mn82:31.1: And what is decay due to sickness?
translation_text.mn82:31.2: It’s when someone is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
translation_text.mn82:31.5: It’s not easy for me to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth I’ve already acquired.
